On the point of definition, Bourdieu (1993) argues that “every literary field is the site of struggle over the definition of the writer,” and that “every survey aimed at establishing the hierarchy of writers predetermines the hierarchy by determining the popula-Notes to Chapter 3 265 tion deemed worthy of helping to establish it.” Given this predicament, “the boundary of the field is a stake of struggles, and the social scientist’s task is not to draw a dividing-line between agents involved in it, by imposing socalled operational definitions” (42). One way around Bourdieu’s concern may be the usage of respondent-driven sampling
